awd_titl_txt: La Serena School for Data Science:  Applied Tools for Astroinformatics, Biomedical Informatics, and Other Data-driven Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The volume and complexity of scientific data continue to grow rapidly.  New astronomical surveys will result in datasets much larger than those previously available.  This poses new challenges for data-driven discovery.  It also enables new opportunities for interdisciplinary research.  Astronomy is at the forefront in creating "pi-shaped" data scientists.  These people have both science expertise and cross-disciplinary knowledge.  Many other fields also see the need for such pi-shaped scientists.  The La Serena School for Data Science 2017-2021 will introduce undergraduates and graduates to the tools and techniques they need.  They will be ready just in time for the large scientific projects of 2020 and beyond.

The existence of enormous (peta-scale) datasets coming from wide-area and time-domain astronomical surveys poses significant concerns for data-driven discovery, access, and analysis, even while enabling new opportunities for interdisciplinary research in applied mathematics, statistics, machine learning, and related topics.  Astronomy provides a sandbox where scientists can come together from diverse fields to address common challenges within the "Big Data" paradigm.  The one-week La Serena School, each year from 2017 to 2021, will train the next generation of scientists in astronomy, biomedicine, computer science, statistics, and mathematics, from the US, Chile and other countries, in the tools and techniques of massive data.  With the experience gained from this school, participants will be prepared to lead the exploration of the extremely large datasets of tomorrow.  The pilot schools, held from 2013 to 2015, were very successful, both demonstrating the demand, and building a strong foundation for collaboration between the NSF and Chilean institutions.  This award will bring 15-18 U.S. students, roughly half of the class each year, to Chile for a combination of learning about massive data and working side-by-side with their Latin-American and other international colleagues.  Support for the schools is shared with a diverse set of Chilean institutions.  NSF funding is provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering and the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

NOIRLab La Serena School for Data Science Outcomes Report

Project Overview:

With support from this National Science Foundation (NSF) grant Award 1637359, the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) and NOIRLab were able to run the La Serena School for Data Science from 10/01/2016 - 09/30/2024. The School is an intensive 10-day program of interdisciplinary lectures, labs and hands-on custom projects, focused on providing students a background in and unique experience with applying and creating discovery and analysis software in the data-driven sciences, in particular large astronomical data sets. 

Participants received instruction in topics of machine learning, high-performance computing, database management, cloud computing, image analysis, statistics and containerization technologies, taught by an international and interdisciplinary group of professors using real world data and examples from astronomy, physics and biology. Participants worked on team-based projects with access to the National Laboratory for High Performance Computing located at the University of Chile's Center for Mathematical Modeling and datasets from US based telescope surveys, accessible through NOIRLab.  

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

With support from this award, organizers of the La Serena School of Data Science (LSSDS)  have been able to achieve our major goals of 1) provided  opportunities for 300+ students to receive broad instruction in the  use of data science techniques for astronomical research and other STEM fields, 2) supported international collaboration and networking between students and professional researchers  and  3) made a broad range of materials that support data science instruction available for use worldwide through the program's website and the Astro Data Lab science platform.  Students from this program are now poised to take advantage of US investments in astronomical research that require understanding of large datasets, like the Rubin Observatory's Legacy Survey of Space and Time.

Broader Impact Outcomes:

The broader impacts of the school beyond the academic teaching of data science are embedded in the School's main goals and key outcomes.  These impacts include 1) development of the scientific workforce beyond astronomy and physics, 2) development of "soft skills" like interdisciplinary and cross-cultural communication, creative problem solving, emotional intelligence, adaptability, collaboration skills and leadership, 3) cultivating a spirit of international collaboration between and among both students and instructors as part of career development and building international funding partnerships in support of this program.
